title: Alborada (horse)
text:
Alborada (8 March 1995 – February 2012) was a British <a href="Thoroughbred">Thoroughbred</a> <a href="horse%20racing">racehorse</a> and <a href="broodmare">broodmare</a> best known for winning consecutive runnings of the Group One <a href="Champion%20Stakes">Champion Stakes</a> at <a href="Newmarket%20Racecourse">Newmarket Racecourse</a>. In a racing career which lasted from July 1997 until October 1999 she won six of her ten races. In addition to her wins in the Champion Stakes she also won the <a href="C.%20L.%20Weld%20Park%20Stakes">C. L. Weld Park Stakes</a> in 1997 and the <a href="Pretty%20Polly%20Stakes%20%28Ireland%29">Pretty Polly Stakes</a> and the <a href="Nassau%20Stakes">Nassau Stakes</a> in 1998. Following her retirement from racing she had some success as a dam of winners.
Background.
Alborada was a grey mare bred by her owner Kirsten Rausing at the Lanwades Stud at <a href="Moulton%2C%20Suffolk">Moulton</a> near <a href="Newmarket%2C%20Suffolk">Newmarket</a>. She was sired by Alzao, a son of <a href="Lyphard">Lyphard</a> who never won above Group Three level, but became a successful breeding stallion, with his progeny including Maraahel (<a href="Hardwicke%20Stakes">Hardwicke Stakes</a>), <a href="Winona%20%28horse%29">Winona</a>, <a href="Second%20Set%20%28horse%29">Second Set</a> and <a href="Shahtoush">Shahtoush</a>. Alborada's dam Alouette, from whom she inherited her grey colour, won three races including the Listed Oyster Stakes at <a href="Galway%20Racecourse">Galway Racecourse</a> in 1993 and was a half-sister of the <a href="Doncaster%20Cup">Doncaster Cup</a>-winning filly <a href="Alleluia%20%28horse%29">Alleluia</a> and Last Second, the winner of the Nassau Stakes and <a href="Sun%20Chariot%20Stakes">Sun Chariot Stakes</a>. After her retirement from racing, Alouette became a successful broodmare: in addition to Alborada, she produced Albanova, a German-trained filly who won the <a href="Grosser%20Preis%20von%20Berlin">Grosser Preis von Berlin</a> <a href="Rheinland-Pokal">Rheinland-Pokal</a>, <a href="Preis%20von%20Europa">Preis von Europa</a> in 2004.
The filly fractured a pedal bone as a foal and could not be sent to the sales. Rausing therefore decided to race Alborada in her own colours and sent her into training with <a href="Mark%20Prescott">Sir Mark Prescott</a> at the Heath House stable in Newmarket. She was ridden in all but one of her races by the veteran British jockey <a href="George%20Duffield">George Duffield</a>.
Racing career.
1997: two-year-old season.
Alborada made her racecourse debut on 19 July in a six <a href="furlong">furlong</a> <a href="maiden%20race">maiden race</a> at <a href="Nottingham%20Racecourse">Nottingham Racecourse</a>. She started <a href="Fractional%20odds">2/1</a> favourite but after meeting interference in the closing stages she finished third of the seventeen runners behind Dazilyn Lady. Twelve days later at <a href="Goodwood%20Racecourse">Goodwood Racecourse</a> she contested a similar event and finished third to Midnight Line, a filly who went on to finish third in <a href="Epsom%20Oaks">The Oaks</a> and win the <a href="Long%20Island%20Handicap">Long Island Handicap</a>. On 17 September Alborada ran in a maiden race over seven and a half furlongs at <a href="Beverley%20Racecourse">Beverley Racecourse</a>. She started the 2/5 favourite and led from the start to win by six lengths to record her first victory. In October, the filly was moved up in class when she was sent to Ireland to contest the Group Three Park Stakes at the <a href="Curragh%20Racecourse">Curragh</a>. On this occasion she was ridden by <a href="Seb%20Sanders">Seb Sanders</a> and started 3/1 favourite against nine opponents. Alborada took the lead inside the final quarter mile and went clear in the closing stages to win by two lengths from Winona, with the future Oaks winner <a href="Shahtoush">Shahtoush</a> in fourth.
1998: three-year-old season.
Alborada did not race in the spring of 1998, missing races such as the <a href="1000%20Guineas">1000 Guineas</a> and the Epsom Oaks as the Heath House stable was affected by an outbreak of <a href="equine%20influenza">equine influenza</a>. The filly also missed an intended engagement in the <a href="Coronation%20Stakes">Coronation Stakes</a> at <a href="Royal%20Ascot">Royal Ascot</a> and did not reappear until 27 June when she was sent to the Curragh again for the Irish Pretty Polly Stakes (then a Group Two race). Racing over ten furlongs on soft ground, she started the 7/4 favourite and won "comfortably" by two and a half lengths. On 1 August at Goodwood she raced in Britain for the first time in ten and a half months when she ran in the Group Two Nassau Stakes. Starting at odds of 4/1 she took the lead inside the final furlong and won by half a length from the 25/1 outsider Digitalize, with Midnight Line in third.
On 12 September, Alborada ran in her first Group One race when she was matched against <a href="colt%20%28horse%29">colts</a> and older horses in the <a href="Irish%20Champion%20Stakes">Esat Digifone Champion Stakes</a> at <a href="Leopardstown%20Racecourse">Leopardstown Racecourse</a>. Her rivals included the dual <a href="King%20George%20VI%20and%20Queen%20Elizabeth%20Stakes">King George VI and Queen Elizabeth Stakes</a> winner <a href="Swain%20%28horse%29">Swain</a>, the <a href="International%20Stakes">International Stakes</a> winner <a href="One%20So%20Wonderful">One So Wonderful</a>, the Oaks winner Shahtoush, the <a href="Irish%201%2C000%20Guineas">Irish 1,000 Guineas</a> winner Tarascon and the 1997 <a href="Cartier%20Champion%20Two-year-old%20Colt">European Champion two-year-old</a> <a href="Xaar">Xaar</a>. Duffield settled the filly in third place before moving into second in the straight. She could make no further progress and finished second of the eight runners behind Swain. On her final appearance of the season, Alborada contested the Champion Stakes over ten furlongs at Newmarket on 17 October and started at odds of 6/1, with <a href="Daylami">Daylami</a> being made the odds-on favourite. After tracking the leaders for most of the way, Alborada took the lead approaching the final furlong and held the late challenge of Insatiable to win by a neck, with Daylami in third. The unplaced horses included One So Wonderful and the future <a href="Arlington%20Million">Arlington Million</a> winner <a href="Chester%20House">Chester House</a>. The win was enthusiastically received by the Newmarket crowd, reflecting the popularity of her jockey and trainer. Commenting on the stresses involved in training a top-class racehorse, Prescott commented: "You spend a lifetime watching races like this and wishing you could have a runner that good; and when you do it kills you."
1999: four-year-old season.
Alborada raced only twice as a four-year-old in 1999 as her season was disrupted by injury. On 31 July she started the 15/8 favourite for the Nassau Stakes, (run for the first time as a Group One race) but finished fifth behind the three-year-old Zahrat Dubai. Prescott could offer no explanation for the filly's poor performance.
On 16 October, Alborada attempted to become the second female racecourse (after <a href="Triptych%20%28horse%29">Triptych</a>) to win consecutive runnings of the <a href="Champion%20Stakes">Champion Stakes</a>. The Japanese-bred filly Shiva, winner of the <a href="Tattersalls%20Gold%20Cup">Tattersalls Gold Cup</a>, started favourite ahead of Lear Spear who had defeated <a href="Fantastic%20Light">Fantastic Light</a> in the <a href="Prince%20of%20Wales%27s%20Stakes">Prince of Wales's Stakes</a> at <a href="Royal%20Ascot">Royal Ascot</a>, while Alborada shared third place in the betting with the 1998 Epsom Derby winner <a href="High-Rise%20%28horse%29">High-Rise</a>. The fifty-two-year-old Duffield tracked the leaders before sending Alborada into the lead approaching the final furlong and she won the race by one and a quarter lengths from Shiva, with Kabool in third. After the race Prescott admitted that he had considered retiring the filly in September after her injury problems and poor performances in training. Duffield said "she's an absolute superstar and this is a bonus for me at my age." Kirsten Rausing called Alborada "a filly for the history books; a great filly who will always be remembered in Newmarket."
Stud record.
Alborada was retired from racing to become a broodmare at the Lanwades Stud. She has produced at least three winners:
She produced her last foal, a colt sired by Archipenko in February 2012, but died shortly after delivering the foal.
